resources.string: Permission for location has been denied
Permission for storage has been denied
Octet-gram of cloud cover, blue is for clear while white is for cloud. e.g. the \"cake\" on the left is 0% cloud while the one on the right is 100% cloud.
Astronomical seeing. From left to right: <0.5″, 0.5″–0.75″, 0.75″–1″, 1″–1.25″, 1.25″–1.5″, 1.5″–2″, 2″–2.5″, >2.5″. In short, the smaller/bluer, the better the seeing condition is.
Atmospheric transparency. From left to right: <0.3, 0.3–0.4, 0.4–0.5, 0.5–0.6, 0.6–0.7, 0.7–0.85, 0.85–1, >1 (unit: mag per air mass). In short, the fewer bars/bluer, the better the transparency is.
Atmospheric instability. From left to right: lifted index between 0 to −3, −3 to −5, and below −5.
Humid weather warning. From left to right: relative humidity between 80%–90%, 90%–95%, and over 95%.
Windy weather warning. From left to right: sustained wind speed between 8.0–10.8m/s (fresh), 10.8–17.2m/s (strong), and over 17.2m/s (gale or above).
Wind direction indicator, an up arrow indicates south wind(wind coming from south).
7Timer service is currently unavailable, show Clear Sky results instead?

7Timer! is a series of web-based meteorological forecast products, mainly derived from the NOAA/NCEP-based numeric weather model, the Global Forecast System (GFS). 7Timer! was firstly established in July 2005 as an exploration product under supported of the National Astronomical Observatories of China and had been largely renovated in 2008 and 2011. Currently it is supported by the Shanghai Astronomical Observatory of Chinese Academy of Sciences. It was firstly designed as a weather forecast tool for astronomical purpose, as the author himself is a long-term star gazer and was always annoyed by fluky weather conditions.

Resources for the light pollution map are from World Atlas 2015.\n\nCredits: Falchi, Fabio; Cinzano, Pierantonio; Duriscoe, Dan; Kyba, Christopher C. M.; Elvidge, Christopher D.; Baugh, Kimberly; Portnov, Boris; Rybnikova, Nataliya A.; Furgoni, Riccardo (2016): Supplement to: The New World Atlas of Artificial Night Sky Brightness. GFZ Data Services. http://doi.org/10.5880/GFZ.1.4.2016.001 Falchi F, Cinzano P, Duriscoe D, Kyba CC, Elvidge CD, Baugh K, Portnov BA, Rybnikova NA, Furgoni R. The new world atlas of artificial night sky brightness. Science Advances. 2016 Jun 1;2(6):e1600377.
Rise and set times for astro objects are calculated on your device without the need of Internet connection.
Ads will be disabled for 1 day, restart Astroweather to take effect. Alternatively, you can also purchase Astroweather PRO to disable ads entirely.

WebView is not installed on this device, Quanzi is unavailable.
View the next time when a spacecraft passes

This page shows the sun rise/set position as well as sun\'s current position in the location you choose.\nThe two red lines are the directions of sun when it rises and sets. The other line is sun\'s current direction.

This page shows the information for passes of a specific spacecraft in the location you choose within 10 days.\nMultiple factors could result in passes being not observable, for example, solar altitude. By toggling \"Observable Passes\", you can choose to see a full list of passes or a list of passes observable for you.
This page shows the sky chart at a specific time in the location you choose.\nLeft → East, Top → North, Right → West, Bottom → South.\nYou can configure the sky chart by changing some settings.
Click here to get definitions of each value.\nYou can also try tapping on some of the elements to see the values they represent.
Map Legend. Tap color squares to see their definitions.
Ratio to natural brightness: < 0.01\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): < 1.74\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): < 0.176
Ratio to natural brightness: 0.01 – 0.02\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 1.74 – 3.48\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 0.176 – 0.177
Ratio to natural brightness: 0.02 – 0.04\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 3.48 – 6.96\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 0.177 – 0.181
Ratio to natural brightness: 0.04 – 0.08\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 6.96 – 13.9\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 0.181 – 0.188
Ratio to natural brightness: 0.08 – 0.16\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 13.9 – 27.8\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 0.188 – 0.202
Ratio to natural brightness: 0.16 – 0.32\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 27.8 – 55.7\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 0.202 – 0.230
Ratio to natural brightness: 0.32 – 0.64\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 55.7 – 111\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 0.230 – 0.285
Ratio to natural brightness: 0.64 – 1.28\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 111 – 223\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 0.285 – 0.397
Ratio to natural brightness: 1.28 – 2.56\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 223 – 445\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 0.397 – 0.619
Ratio to natural brightness: 2.56 – 5.12\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 445 – 890\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 0.619 – 1.065
Ratio to natural brightness: 5.12 – 10.2\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 890 – 1780\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 1.065 – 1.96
Ratio to natural brightness: 10.2 – 20.5\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 1780 – 3560\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 1.96 – 3.74
Ratio to natural brightness: 20.5 – 41\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): 3560 – 7130\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): 3.74 – 7.30
Ratio to natural brightness: > 41\nArtificial brightness (μcd/m²): > 7130\nApproximate total brightness (mcd/m²): > 7.30
The blue curve shows the trail of the spacecraft.
The blue curve shows the trail of the spacecraft. The white part of the curve is the part that can be observed.
To view information from your current location, Astroweather will now request for permission to access your device location.
